screening_results.reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of racial ingroup vs outgroup faces) in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black subjects). The paper reports group-level task-evoked BOLD differences in the amygdala to outgroup versus ingroup faces and describes voxelwise identification of those voxels followed by an ROI analysis, indicating whole-brain voxelwise effects were evaluated and reported for the healthy sample. No clinical or out-of-range-age groups dominate the reported results. Therefore it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; group-level univariate voxelwise/ROI-reported effects stemming from identified voxels). Confidence is somewhat reduced due to limited detail in the abstract about full tables/figures of whole-brain results, but the description indicates appropriate group-level voxelwise findings.

The provided full text contains only the reference list and bibliographic details; there is no information on participants, task design, or reported results. Inclusion requires explicit reporting of at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map for healthy adult participants (age 17–65). I cannot verify sample characteristics (healthy adults), whether whole-brain voxelwise analyses were performed, or whether healthy-group results are reported separately. While the title suggests an fMRI study of gaze and fusiform activity, the available content does not confirm the key inclusion criteria and may instead report connectivity (coupling) analyses, which would be excluded if no whole-brain activation maps are provided. Therefore the study is excluded due to insufficient information to confirm the required whole-brain healthy-group task activation evidence.

Full text content provided contains only the References and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant demographics, task description, or results are available. Therefore it is impossible to verify key inclusion criteria: that the study used task-based fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults (age 17–65), and that it reports at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because these required elements cannot be confirmed from the provided material, the study cannot be included in the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=8 in the fMRI sample) examining social gaze processing (a social-perception/communication construct). In addition to ROI analyses, the paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps (across-subjects t-statistic maps displayed on a standard brain and described in the text) identifying STS and FFG activations. The healthy/control group is clearly reported separately. Although the primary analysis emphasized anatomically defined ROIs and the group voxelwise maps were produced using a fixed-effects averaging approach (limited generalizability), the manuscript nevertheless provides univariate, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults, satisfying the inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI on face perception (a social-perception task) in healthy adults, the provided full-text summary does not report key required details: participant age range and whether group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps were reported. The abstract describes regional responses (FFA, STS, amygdala) but does not confirm whole-brain voxelwise results versus ROI-based analyses. Because the inclusion criteria require explicit reporting of healthy adult sample(s) and at least one whole-brain, group-level univariate task map, and these are not clearly documented in the supplied text, the study must be excluded. If full text provides coordinate tables or whole-brain maps elsewhere, re-screening would be appropriate.

This is an fMRI investigation of social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5, N=10 in Study 1 and N=12 in Study 2). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (subtractive contrasts vs fixation, 3-versus-1 contrasts), with Talairach coordinates and random-effects analyses, generalizable to healthy adults. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) in adults using a task manipulating self vs. other and perspective taking. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial prefrontal cortex (ventral/dorsal anterior MPFC, posterior dorsal MPFC, and left dorsal MPFC) consistent with whole-brain voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only results. Participants are healthy adults (typical for this JCN experimental study) and results are reported as generalizable group effects. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only, and it presents univariate whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing, which qualifies as social communication/social-related processing. It reports data from a group of 12 healthy subjects and describes group-level BOLD signal increases for implicit and explicit conditions and their direct comparison (listing multiple brain regions), indicating univariate whole-brain task-evoked results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level activation maps. Uncertainty remains because the abstract does not explicitly state participant ages (17–65 requirement) and the full text/PDF was not accessible to verify exact methods (e.g., that analyses were voxelwise whole-brain and not ROI-masked). For these reasons I include the study with moderate-high confidence (0.80).

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=16 after exclusions) and reports group-level ROI and voxelwise ANOVA results with Talairach/MNI coordinates, the manuscript’s voxelwise analyses were explicitly restricted to predefined regions (DLPFC, superior temporal regions, somatosensory and visual cortex, and later masked analyses including medial prefrontal areas). The paper primarily reports ROI-based contrasts and masked voxelwise results rather than an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map. The inclusion criteria require at least one univariate, whole-brain (voxelwise) group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Because the reported voxelwise results were region-restricted/masked and no unmasked whole-brain statistical map for the healthy group is presented, the study does not meet the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (perception of others' emotional facial expressions/empathy). The sample is 14 healthy adults (mean 29±6 years), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise statistical parametric mapping results identifying dorsal medial frontal cortex/pre-SMA activation during emotion perception, satisfying the whole-brain univariate activation requirement (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Results are described as generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38). The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain analyses (one-sample t-test contrasting all ToM conditions vs. non-ToM and report peaks/coordinates) and provide voxelwise contrasts between conditions (reported as second-level paired t-tests and coordinate peaks). Whole-brain results are described and thresholded (p<0.02, k≥15) and anatomical coordinates are given. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

The study is an original task-based fMRI investigation in healthy adult participants examining perception/understanding of self versus others (own vs. others' body parts), which fits the review’s social-related constructs. Sample consists of healthy adults (n=12–15 per experiment). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain contrasts used for ROI localization (e.g., body minus objects localizer; coordinates and voxel counts for EBA, V1/2, LOC are provided and thresholding is described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results in the healthy group. Although key adaptation analyses are conducted within subject-specific ROIs, the manuscript includes whole-brain contrast results (tables/coordinates) and is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related auditory task (perception/understanding of others: distinguishing one vs two walkers). Sample comprises 12 healthy adults aged 22–37 (within 17–65). The authors report group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2), including statistical maps, Talairach coordinates, and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity and results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI study reanalyzed with FIR focusing on perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Participants: 17 healthy right-handed adult males (mean age 25.9), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVA; SPM; threshold p=.001 uncorrected; coordinates and activation tables/figures provided for main effects and time-bin contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26, range within 17–65). The task investigates social cognition (observation of social vs. individual actions and effects of gaze), which falls squarely within social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects and interaction), with SPM results, coordinate tables, and statistical maps (p<.001 uncorrected) clearly described for the healthy participant group. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only limitations apply. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated, so the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 22) examining social-related processing (perception of others’ pupillary responses and their social salience). The study reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (main effects of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected thresholds and effects of pupil change reported with cluster thresholds), and presents voxelwise activations (including tables/coordinates and figures). The task is social/perceptual and maps are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult group reported separately).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (explicit emotion recognition of facial expressions) in healthy adult males (age 21–33). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain (‘‘whole-slab’’) analyses and activation maps (e.g., Figure 2) and provides cluster coordinates/ANOVA results from whole-brain analyses (parahippocampal gyrus; inferior frontal gyrus coordinates reported). Although ROI analyses are also performed for the amygdala, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy sample are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults and reports group-level voxelwise task contrasts (AV, VIS, AUD vs rest, and AV vs ApV), the fMRI acquisition used a split-sagittal, partial-volume protocol that explicitly excluded medial regions and other large portions of the brain (e.g., medial frontal/parietal cortex, fusiform and early visual cortex). The review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the imaging did not provide whole-brain coverage, the reported voxelwise results are limited to a restricted volume and do not meet the ‘whole-brain’ requirement. All other criteria (healthy adult sample, group-level voxelwise analyses) are met, but failure to provide whole-brain coverage necessitates exclusion.

Although this is an fMRI study of social communication/emotional perception in healthy adults (n=24, ages 18–41) and reports group-level contrasts within the superior temporal sulcus (STS), the analyses are ROI-based using individually mapped STS measuring points. Statistical tests and reported T-values derive from parameter estimates extracted from these ROIs (MPs) rather than from a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map. The paper emphasizes a region-of-interest approach and reports effects at MP centroids; it does not present an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise activation map or whole-brain coordinate table arising from a voxelwise group analysis. This violates the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion, so the study must be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI probing self- and social-cognitive processes (direct and reflected self-appraisals). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) reported separately from adolescents. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, unmasked voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests and conjunctions for each appraisal condition in adults vs rest; interaction and between-group whole-brain contrasts) with coordinates and figures, corrected for multiple comparisons—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (prosody perception/production and empathy) in healthy adults (n=19; age 18–58). Group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) using random-effects analyses with FDR correction and cluster reporting; results and coordinates are described in the text and supplementary materials. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (18 analyzed; mean age 27.5), meeting the sample criterion (ages within 17–65). The experiment used task-based fMRI during a social communication task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (GLM-derived activations used to define mirror ROIs, references to GLM results and figures/SI showing clusters), and presents univariate results in the main text and supplementary figures/tables. Although the manuscript emphasizes between-brain Granger-causality mapping, it also includes traditional GLM whole-brain analyses (and seed ROI definitions based on these), so it is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (ages within range) and reports group-level contrasts, the reported results are primarily ROI-based using small-volume correction (amygdala, insula, striatum, OFC) rather than unmasked, whole‑brain voxelwise task activation maps. Methods and results emphasize SVC/ROI analyses and present ROI-corrected findings; I find no clear presentation of an unqualified whole‑brain, group-level task activation map (or whole‑brain coordinate table) generalizable to the healthy adult group. Per the review’s exclusion criteria (studies reporting only ROI/SVC results without whole‑brain task maps), this study should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=98, mean age 20.7) using social-related tasks (self/close others/strangers attribute and preference judgments), matching the review constructs (perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., self > Bush; friends > strangers) with voxelwise maps and thresholding (p<0.001) presented in figures and described in the text. Results for the healthy participants are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study includes both whole-brain analyses and ROI follow-ups, so it does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI results from a mixed-age sample (N=57; ages 7–40) and focuses on continuous, age-related correlations and whole-group maps that include children, adolescents, and adults. Although healthy adults (up to age 40) are included, the paper does not present a separate group-level univariate whole-brain activation map or contrast explicitly restricted to a healthy adult subgroup (age 17–65) that would be generalizable to the adult population. Inclusion criteria require at least one healthy adult group reported separately with whole-brain task-evoked results. Because no adult-only group-level whole-brain results are reported, the study does not meet the review’s inclusion requirements.

The study samples adolescents across three developmental phases (adolescence) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. The full text/abstract does not report a separate healthy adult group or results for adults. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group (17–65) analyzed and reported separately, this study fails the sample inclusion criterion and must be excluded. (Unable to verify adult subgroup or exclusively adult whole-brain results from the provided text.)

This fMRI study investigates face individuation, which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Sample comprises healthy adults (final N=15, mean age 24.8), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses for the individuation task (repeated-measures ANOVA across participants with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction), with whole-brain contrasts and reported regional activations; thus whole-brain, task-evoked maps for the healthy group are available. The study also includes ROI analyses but is not limited to them. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observing social interactions vs non-social movements) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 29.4). It reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation contrasts (SI > NSI) using random-effects one-sample t-tests with FDR correction (p<0.05) and lists activated clusters/locations. The task probes social perception/understanding of others via point-light displays. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and presents univariate whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=16 analyzed; ages 19–24) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain analyses (e.g., contrasts for Morph 50% recognized as self vs friend) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level family-wise error correction; coordinates and activated clusters (MPFC, PCC, precuneus) are reported. Thus it provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (observing virtual social interactions). Participants are healthy adults (protocol describes recruitment by age/health and Figure 1 notes group data from 15 participants). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activation maps/contrasts (social interaction vs. control) with activations in STS, mPFC, and amygdala — i.e., univariate whole-brain results generalizable to the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor non-empirical. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study (Cyberball) probing social exclusion—clearly a social-related construct (affiliation/belonging). Sample consists of healthy adults (n=20 analyzed; ages ~25), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables/figures of coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (male, age 23–28). The paper reports whole-brain offline analyses: cross-subject whole-brain classification, extraction of discriminating volumes mapped back into voxel space, and voxelwise significance testing (permutation-based p-values, reported discriminating volumes and anatomical loci). Results are presented at the group level and generalize across subjects (leave-one-subject-out cross-subject model). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample within age range, and (3) group-level whole-brain voxelwise results (discriminating volumes with voxelwise p-values and reported regions). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension that specifically contrasts complex (including social emotions: proud, guilty) versus simple emotions, addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=19 males, age 18–51), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple), analyzed in SPM8 with corrected cluster-wise inference and reported activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (right-handed Caucasian males, ages 17–43) using a social task manipulating minimal in-group vs out-group membership and action perception. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., action videos vs fixation; own-team vs other-team; decision vs press) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides peak coordinates and cluster statistics. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (20 women, ages 18–52) using a social cognition task probing self- and other-referential processing (valenced SRP/ORP), which falls squarely under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., S-N vs baseline, S-P vs baseline, and planned contrasts S-N vs S-P, S-N vs O-N, S-P vs O-P) analyzed with SPM8 and provides voxelwise maps, cluster results and coordinates (voxel-wise P<0.005 with cluster thresholds, tables/figures). Results are presented for the healthy sample without restriction to a narrow subgroup. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social evaluation (impression formation), addressing social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant), conjunction analyses, corrected cluster results, and ROI percent-signal-change characterization — not ROI-only or connectivity-only. The sample includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29) within the 17–65 range and reports separate group-level results for age groups, so acceptable despite also including an older (>65) group. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task activation in healthy adults and should be INCLUDED.

Although the study includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–45) and uses task-based fMRI, the reported whole-brain voxelwise results focus on developmental (between-group) contrasts and age-related effects rather than an unmasked, whole-brain within-group task activation map clearly attributable to the healthy adult group alone. The paper reports ROI-based within-group follow-up tests for adults but does not present a standalone, group-level, whole-brain task activation map (or within-group voxelwise contrasts) for the adult sample that would be generalizable to the healthy adult population. According to the exclusion criteria, studies reporting only between-group contrasts or ROI-based within-group tests without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (understanding social intentions/cooperative vs. affective interactions) in healthy adult participants (N=27; ages ~24–26), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects, full-factorial second-level analyses) with whole-brain statistical maps and FWE-corrected results, plus coordinate tables and conjunction/contrast maps; results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (N=19; ages 21–34). Participants performed a social-related task (watching naturalistic movie clips annotated for social features). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate GLM analyses (first- and second-level random-effects; one-sample t-tests), whole-brain statistical maps (p<0.05 FDR corrected) and coordinates/figures describing activations for social vs. non-social contrasts and individual social features. No ROI-only or resting-state-only analyses. Results for healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (attachment/affiliation) using a task (own infant cry) in adult participants (22 primiparous mothers; mean age 24.1, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (own cry > control/other cry) with cluster-thresholding and MNI coordinates, meeting whole-brain reporting requirements. Although the sample includes some mothers with past perinatal depression and three on SSRIs, none met current MDD at scanning and analyses examined depressive symptoms as covariates; results are reported for the overall (healthy) group. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain task activation in healthy adults and is appropriate for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding/mentalizing) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32). It uses a task-based within-subjects design manipulating cognitive load and social inference goals, and reports group-level, random-effects univariate voxelwise analyses with reported cluster coordinates and contrasts (mask and whole-brain results referenced in Supplemental Methods). Results include cluster-wise corrected activations (e.g., mirror neuron and mentalizing system regions) and contrast maps (e.g., conjunctions, load×goal interactions) from the healthy sample. The paper is empirical, not connectivity- or ROI-only, and reports healthy-group task activations generalizable to typical adults. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI task clearly probes social-related processing (action observation/execution and mirror-system responses relevant to perception/understanding of others); (2) Sample = 21 healthy adults (mean age 24), within 17–65 range; (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (random-effects contrasts; whole-brain threshold p<0.001 uncorrected reported along with ROI/FWE results) with peak coordinates and SPMs applicable to the healthy group. Not excluded: results are not ROI-only (whole-brain reported), not connectivity-only, and participants are healthy adults. Therefore include for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 25). The task contrasts interactive (ostensive) versus observational conditions—clearly social-related constructs (social communication/interaction, perception of others). Group-level fMRI analyses were conducted (two-group RFX analyses using a whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA), and results are reported at the group level. Although the authors used ROI small-volume corrections for key hypotheses, they also report results from whole-brain analyses (exploratory whole-brain activity in early visual cortex) and describe whole-brain RFX procedures and thresholding, satisfying the requirement for group-level univariate voxelwise task-evoked results in healthy adults. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=15 after exclusion; ages 19–42) that examines perception of others’ gender from faces — a social-perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports both ROI analyses and a whole-brain random-effects voxel-wise group analysis (contrast gender-different > gender-same) with statistical thresholding and reported clusters/coordinates (right collateral sulcus, left precuneus, right lateral occipital gyrus, right putamen). Thus it provides a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI analyses, resting-state, or non-healthy sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=15, mean age ~24) using a social inclusion/exclusion paradigm, the paper’s primary results are multivariate (ROI-based SVM decoding and a searchlight correlation MVPA). The manuscript does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (voxelwise contrast) for the healthy sample: univariate SPM group analyses for the key interaction yielded no significant voxels surviving correction and no whole-brain univariate contrasts/coordinates are presented as healthy-group task activations. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast) from the healthy adults, this study does not meet the whole-brain univariate evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and evaluation of different laughter types; explicit laughter-type categorization vs implicit counting) in healthy adults (n=18, mean age 26±3.4, right-handed). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., CSL>TIC, TIC>CSL, CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and describes whole-brain results in text, figures and tables. Thus it provides whole-brain, task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (message propagation, mentalizing, reward) using a task where participants encoded and recommended TV-show ideas. Sample: healthy adults (interns N=19, mean age 20.55) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (buzz, intention, salesperson effects) with MNI coordinates, thresholding, and tables/figures—i.e., whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from the healthy group. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrasts only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of third-party punishment, a social-cognition task (attribution of intentions/beliefs). Sample: 26 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 26), within 17–65. Analyses: whole-brain, random-effects GLM with voxelwise statistics (reported threshold q(FDR)<0.05) and reported Talairach coordinates for group-level activations (R TPJ, R anterior insula), satisfying univariate whole-brain task-evoked reporting. Results are reported for the healthy control sample. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses and is empirical with original fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review/theoretical paper summarizing fMRI and computational findings rather than reporting original empirical fMRI data. The full text and abstract describe conceptual discussion and prior findings but provide no participant/sample details, no methods section with fMRI acquisition/analysis, and no group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps or coordinate tables for a healthy adult sample. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for original whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

This is an original task-based fMRI study of social cognition (attribute framing/self and reflected perspectives). Sample: healthy adults aged 19–41 (group-level results reported; two exclusions noted). Whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses are reported (GLM contrasts such as task>control, positive>negative, frame-inconsistent>frame-consistent) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-size correction, and stereotactic coordinates presented in the text/figures. Results are group-level and generalizable to healthy adults (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The paper is empirical and reports primary fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (evaluation of face approachability — perception/understanding of others). The sample appears to be healthy adult participants. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (interaction between task and face valence) and lists activations in left amygdala, medial/middle/inferior frontal gyri; BOLD responses and correlations with trait anxiety are reported. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate group results) are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication/empathy using naturalistic video stimuli in healthy adults (N=27; mean age 34, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate GLM contrasts and conjunctions (e.g., emotional vs neutral contrasts, region activations in fusiform gyrus, auditory cortex, angular gyrus) derived from whole-brain analyses and presents coordinates/figures, not solely ROI or connectivity results. Although it also includes DCM (effective connectivity) and ROI-based FIR analyses, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy sample are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is a task fMRI study of healthy adults examining interpersonal (social) touch, the reported results are derived from group independent component analysis (ICA) spatial maps and component time courses. The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main effects or within-group voxelwise contrasts) for the healthy sample. Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only ICA/related multivariate or connectivity analyses without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded. All other inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task involving social touch) are met, but the absence of an univariate whole-brain task map leads to exclusion.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=15, ages 20–28) performing social-distance judgments (names/photos of friends vs acquaintances) — a social-processing task (Perception/Understanding of Others). The authors conducted group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses (GLM; paired t tests and conjunction analyses across within-domain contrasts) and explicitly report whole-brain univariate results (noting no voxels survived FDR-corrected thresholds), satisfying the requirement to report group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy sample. Although the paper emphasizes MVPA/RSA findings, the univariate whole-brain analyses are present and clearly described. Sample falls within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct self, direct other, and reflected self evaluations — social cognition and self-perception). It includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) within the 17–65 range. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses were conducted (2×4×3 whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA) with multiple-comparison correction (voxel-wise p<0.005, cluster k=64, FWE-corrected) and results (main effects/interactions and follow-up contrasts) are described in the text and supplementary materials. The paper therefore provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/generalizable group results for healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) apply. Hence the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (attributing awareness to another) in healthy adults (fMRI sample n=50, ages 18–49). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (H trials − E trials) thresholded at P < 0.05 corrected with cluster-size correction, with coordinates provided (Table 1) and surface maps (Fig. 3). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not a between-group-only contrast, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 22.5, range 19–29), investigating self- and other-referential processing (conceptual and agentic self/other recollection)—constructs squarely fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ and social cognition. The paper reports group-level univariate task-evoked whole-brain analyses (conjunctions, old>new contrasts, and whole-brain FWE-corrected results) and provides coordinates and cluster statistics; although an mPFC ROI was used for small-volume correction, whole-brain results are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants that used a social-feedback task (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation results (e.g., main effects and parametric modulators with whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters in ACC/MPFC, ventral striatum, TPJ, etc.), clearly described for the healthy participant groups. Sample comprises healthy adult German and Chinese participants within typical adult age range. Analyses include whole-brain contrasts and tables of activations; results for the healthy groups are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study tests a social task (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adults (N=28, mean age ~25) and reports group-level task contrasts. However, the second-level analyses were performed using a restricted a priori mask composed of 16 bilateral ROIs (wfu_pickatlas), and all reported statistical inferences were made within that mask. Thus the paper reports ROI-constrained voxelwise results rather than an unmasked whole-brain group-level task activation map. According to the review’s criteria, studies that report only ROI analyses without whole-brain task activation are excluded. Although imaging data were whole-brain acquisitions and coordinate tables/figures are provided, the absence of an unmasked whole-brain, group-level univariate map disqualifies inclusion.

This paper reports an fMRI neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony addressing social-affiliative processing (affiliation/social cognition). Participants served as healthy adult referents (sample described across studies; no clinical groups reported separately). The abstract and methods explicitly describe a neuroimaging study demonstrating involvement of brain areas implicated in social and embodied cognition, implying group-level task-evoked activation contrasts (whole-brain task activations) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are apparent (not a review, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and involves healthy adults within the target age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. (Included based on full-text abstract/method summary indicating whole-brain task activation results; if a later check of the full manuscript showed only ROI or connectivity results, this decision would need revision.)

This is an fMRI study examining socio-emotional processing (empathy induction) using campaign videos during task-based fMRI. Sample consists of 20 healthy adult participants (ages 20–28), meeting the healthy adult criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (CV > NV) analyzed with a random-effects one-sample t-test and corrected at p<0.05 FWE, with clusters and peak coordinates reported and used as ROIs. Whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from the healthy/control group are clearly presented in text, tables, and figures. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results) and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not outside age range). Note: sample is all-male and modest N, but this does not disqualify inclusion since criteria are satisfied.

This is an fMRI task study of social perception (point-light biological motion), conducted in healthy adults (N=26 analyzed; ages 18–39). The paper reports both ROI and whole-brain group-level univariate task analyses: whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity with social-network measures are described, with correction for multiple comparisons and a reported significant cluster in right pSTS/TPJ. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and at least one group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical result). No exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related task (social sharing/affiliation) examining effects of viewing emotional stimuli ‘shared’ vs ‘unshared’ with a friend. (2) Sample: Healthy adult participants (female, ages 20–33), results reported for the healthy group. (3) Whole-brain evidence: Group-level, random-effects univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., shared_emo > unshared_emo) with whole-brain corrected activations (left DLPFC and bilateral precuneus reported at P<0.05 whole-brain corrected) in addition to ROI results. (4) Study is empirical, task-based fMRI and generalizable to healthy adults. Not excluded by ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only criteria. Therefore include in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (25 scanned participants, mean age ~22.6) using a socially relevant task (repeated public good game probing social tie formation/other-regarding preferences). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM results (parametric effects and contrasts) with MNI coordinates and cluster-wise FWE correction; activations and statistical thresholds are clearly described in the text and tables/figures. Results for the healthy scanned group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes task-evoked whole-brain maps (not limited to connectivity-only analyses). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (N=54 right-handed males, ages 18–27). The task is explicitly social/communicative (interactive dyadic game manipulating shared meaning). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM/FSL random-effects, cluster-level FWE correction) identifying regions such as right superior temporal gyrus and provides voxelwise contrasts, parametric modulations, and coordinates. Analyses are task-evoked (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and results for the healthy adult group are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not only connectivity/resting-state, age within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This conference paper lacks essential information to meet inclusion criteria. The abstract does not report participant details or ages (no confirmation of healthy adult sample 17–65). It also does not present or reference any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy/control group—only general statements about a "neural basis" and dyadic analyses. The brief conference format and focus on dyadic instrumentation and network synchronizations suggest methods/novel approach reporting rather than providing the required whole-brain task activation results. Because at least one required inclusion criterion (clear healthy adult sample and whole-brain univariate results) cannot be verified, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of deception in strategic interaction probing theory-of-mind/social cognition (perception/understanding of others), satisfying the social-related task requirement. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=34, age range 21–32), meeting the age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate analyses (Bayesian second-level probability maps and tables of coordinates) for multiple contrasts (e.g., deception vs. truth, sophisticated vs. simple deception, truth vs. deception), which are clearly described for the healthy/control group. The study is empirical original research using task-based fMRI; it does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, nor is it a non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Empirical fMRI study using dyadic fMRI during a social task (face-to-face eye contact). Sample comprises 38 healthy adult participants (19 pairs), ages 18–33, meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results for task A and B, with voxelwise inference thresholds (Z>2.3, p<0.05), cluster tables, MNI coordinates, and probabilistic atlas labels—constituting whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although additional analyses (ICA) are included, whole-brain GLM activations for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI‑only, connectivity‑only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (observed eye contact and gaze following) in healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24.6, all right-handed), which falls within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects one-sample t-tests) with voxelwise contrasts, coordinate tables, figures, and cluster-thresholding procedures, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and reported contrasts directly probe social perception/attention (social communication/perception of others). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, includes healthy-group whole-brain task effects). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20) using social cognitive tasks (ToM, faces, biological motion, voices, language), the reported group-level inferential analyses were restricted to a bilateral STS mask. The paper does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map generalizable to healthy adults; instead results and overlap metrics are derived within the STS ROI and from localized search spaces. This violates the inclusion requirement for at least one whole-brain task-evoked group map, so the study should be excluded.

The study used task-based fMRI during an interactive social/mentalizing paradigm (Prisoner’s Dilemma Game), directly addressing social cognition (mentalizing/attachment). The sample comprises 164 healthy adult subjects (reported as healthy adults), satisfying the healthy adult group requirement. The paper explicitly reports group-level task-evoked neural activations across widespread regions of the mentalizing network (e.g., bilateral precuneus, cingulate cortices, TPJ, IFG, medial frontal gyrus, amygdala), indicating whole-brain univariate task activation results generalizable to the healthy group (not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, and results are reported for healthy participants). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-fMRI study of imitation (social perception/understanding of others), performed in healthy adult participants (n=37, ages 18–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analyses (parametric modulation and second-level random-effects one-sample t-tests) with cluster-corrected thresholds and peak coordinates, and presents activation maps and tables. Although PPI connectivity is also reported, whole-brain task activation results for the healthy adult group are clearly described and generalizable. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task is social-related; sample is healthy adults within 17–65; whole-brain group-level results are reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using Heider–Simmel animations — a clearly social-related task. Sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants (age range 24–64, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (ToM > R and ToM > Baseline) with explicit voxelwise and cluster-level thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected; cluster FWE p<0.05) and reports resulting activations and coordinates (e.g., right TPJ, IFG). Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts, and healthy-group effects are clearly reported. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Population: healthy adult participants (N=46, ages 18–45) meets sample criterion. Task: task-based fMRI using IAPS negative/neutral/positive images (participants viewed images, including people, and rated emotional intensity) — this probes perception/processing of emotional/social stimuli. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (HA− > Neutral) with voxelwise thresholding and reported activated clusters (dmPFC, right amygdala, etc.), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the primary focus is emotion rather than explicit social interaction, dmPFC is discussed in social-cognitive terms and stimuli included social content, so it falls within the review’s broad definition (e.g., perception/understanding of others; social-affective processing). No exclusion criteria are violated (whole-brain results are reported; not ROI-only; healthy adults reported separately). Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observing dyadic violent interactions) in healthy adults (15 male participants; final N=14; mean age 23.6). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others; attentional focus on aggressor vs victim). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM, whole-brain contrasts such as focus on aggressor > focus on victim, FDR/cluster correction) with reported activations (amygdala, ACC, insula, EBA, STS, etc.) and connectivity follow-ups. Results are presented as group-level task-evoked whole-brain effects (not ROI-only), and healthy-group results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, includes appropriate age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28, ages 30–50) using a task that directly probes social-related processing (implicit social stimulus processing and self-referential judgments). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analyses (GLM, ANOVA) and thresholded whole-brain results (FDR-corrected p<0.05, cluster k≥20), including coordinate tables and conjunction/contrast maps for main effects and specific contrasts (self-referential vs social, social vs self-referential). The healthy participant results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range, and is empirical). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (processing agency vs. communion trait words) in healthy adults (n=42; age 18–25). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (contrasts, conjunctions) using SPM8 with AlphaSim correction, and presents coordinates/figures of activations and deactivations for the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and the healthy group results are directly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (speech act comprehension) in healthy adults (n=18 analyzed; ages 18–41). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain voxelwise analyses (contrasts such as Request > Naming) with FDR correction (p<0.05), i.e., univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy/control group. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Insufficient reporting to meet inclusion criteria. The abstract describes BOLD responses to live eye contact (a social task), but the full text provided lacks essential details: no information on participants (sample size, ages, confirmation of healthy adult group), and no clear report of group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables/figures for a healthy/control group. As a conference abstract, it appears preliminary and does not provide whole-brain voxelwise results required by the review. Because at least one inclusion criterion (whole-brain univariate healthy-group task map and sample details) is not confirmed, this study must be excluded.

This conference study reports simultaneous EEG–rt-fMRI correlations targeting the right pSTS as an ROI for neurofeedback. It is a proof-of-concept, ROI-based correlation analysis and does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy adult group. Participant/sample details and healthy-group whole-brain results are not reported in the full text/abstract. Therefore it fails the required "whole-brain evidence" inclusion criterion and is excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 scanned; mean age 25.7, within 17–65). The task probes social-related processing (guilt memory vs hypothetical social scenarios; involves social cognition, agency, and perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; guilt memories vs guilt hypotheticals) thresholded at p<0.001 with cluster extent and reports peak coordinates and figures; SPM8 second-level analyses were performed and whole-brain activations (posterior cingulate, inferior frontal cortices, etc.) are described. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social processing (perception of others' facial expressions — a social communication/Perception of Others task) in a healthy adult sample (n=24, ages in range). The methods describe voxelwise first-level and group-level mixed-effects analyses (FEAT/FLAME) and state that parameter-estimate maps for each expression were generated and registered to MNI space, indicating group-level univariate whole-brain maps were produced. Additionally, a group-level localiser contrast (faces > scrambled faces; n=83) was used to define face-selective ROIs, which is itself a reported group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy participants. The study therefore meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) reporting of group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI or connectivity analyses) prevent inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI study of social processing (person perception and trait inference) using an active task; (2) healthy adult sample (N=21 after exclusions; mean age 24.6, within 17–65); (3) reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, and the interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with thresholding and overlap/coordinate reporting (main text and supplementary tables/figures). The paper also includes localisers and PPI connectivity analyses, but it clearly provides univariate whole-brain results for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=31 analyzed; ages ~21), using a social interaction task (Cyberball) probing affiliation/belonging. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (task-by-frequency interaction: ball-toss high>normal vs button-press high>normal) with coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected significance (ventral striatum, precuneus). Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based whole-brain fMRI study using the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social-interaction paradigm probing retaliation/anger (social-emotional processing). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=15 males, mean age 22.3) reported separately. The paper reports group-level random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (thresholded statistical maps and Talairach coordinates) and parametric modulations—i.e., whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (empathy, perspective taking, attention shifts) in healthy adults (N=33, age range 20–34). The tasks are social and relevant (charitable donation, EmpaToM ToM/empathy task). Group-level, task-evoked whole-brain analyses are reported (random-effects group analyses, GLMs and contrasts; tables of significant clusters/coordinates are provided for EmpaToM and decoding results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task effects generalizable to healthy adults. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. Although some univariate donation contrasts were null at stringent thresholds, the paper nonetheless reports whole-brain group analyses and coordinates for task activations used in subsequent analyses, meeting inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (Ultimatum Game) probing social decision-making (cooperation/fairness). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N≈51; mean ages ~31, within 17–65) with results reported separately for healthy groups. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (pre/post training GLMs, conjunctions, interaction contrasts) with voxelwise statistical maps and coordinates (FDR-corrected results, Tables S1/S2 and figures). Although ROI and PPI analyses are also present, they supplement—not replace—whole-brain task activation results. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within age range and healthy). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and includes social tasks (theory-of-mind and social attribution), but it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group. Analyses rely on localized ICA applied within a temporoparietal ROI and regression of IC time courses, with subsequent seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps. These are ROI-decomposed and connectivity results rather than the required whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., GLM group maps or within-group voxelwise contrasts). Because the paper lacks an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map, it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, ages 23–33) using a social-related task (observing actors grasping objects with emotional contexts; perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate GLM results (main effects and contrasts such as angry vs. joyful; reported whole-brain FWE-corrected activations and ROI and PPI/DCM analyses), with results clearly presented for the healthy sample. All inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain task-evoked group-level maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, no patient-only sample).

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (college-aged participants, N=10 pilot, N=15 main; screened for health, ages ≥18). Tasks are clearly social-related (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum/Welfare Game with socialization manipulations: Human/Acquaintance vs Computer/Random Individual). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (FSL/SPM mixed-effects analyses, cluster-corrected thresholds, tables/coordinates and figures for contrasts such as High sociality > Low sociality and game contrasts), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results are presented as population-generalizable healthy-group contrasts. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, participants within 17–65). Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25; age range 19–26) that explicitly investigates attachment-related (social) processing. The task contrasts attachment-related vs. matched neutral pictures, a social cognition/attachment paradigm directly relevant to the review objective. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation results (attachment vs. neutral and interactions with monadic/dyadic), including voxel coordinates, cluster sizes, t-values, and cluster-level correction thresholds (p<0.05 cluster-corrected with cluster-defining p<0.001), and displays statistical maps/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, includes a healthy adult group with whole-brain task activation maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=24, ages 19–31) examining social cognition (cooperation vs. competition; perception/estimation of self and others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked whole-brain analyses (identifying pgACC and area 9 and other whole-brain effects) and uses these results to define ROIs—i.e., not ROI-only reporting. It is not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalized to the healthy adult sample. Thus it meets inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample within age range, and whole-brain univariate task results reported.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (Prisoner’s Dilemma cooperation) using a task probing social cooperation/valuation. Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=18, mean age 21), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (contrasts comparing CC vs other outcomes; context effects and interactions), with coordinates (MNI) and cluster-level FWE correction reported, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not clinical-only, and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/rest-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are presented). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is a social-processing fMRI paradigm (Face Matching Task with emotional faces — perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results (first- and second-level analyses; contrasts and one-sample t-tests reported with maps/tables referenced in Supplementary Material, Table S2 and Figures S1–S3), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only findings. Although ICA connectivity analyses are also presented, the study includes the required whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group. Therefore it should be included in the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-language processing in healthy adults (n=19, mean age 20.6) using a task where participants viewed product descriptions and later re-described them. The paper reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain analyses (parametric modulators for ‘social language in’ and ‘social language out’) with thresholded whole-brain maps and tables of activations (e.g., Figures 5–6, Tables 4 and 6), not ROI-only results. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical-only, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of a social processing task (face encoding/recognition) in healthy adults, it reports only ROI-based analyses focused on the amygdala. The Methods explicitly state the analysis focused on an a priori amygdala ROI and extraction of parameter estimates; no group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or whole-brain coordinate tables for the healthy group are reported. This violates the inclusion requirement for at least one whole-brain healthy-group task activation map. (Note: the sample includes both young adults and older adults >65, but the primary exclusion is ROI-only reporting.)

This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain (a social cognitive process: perception/understanding of others) conducted in healthy adult participants (male, 18–40). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (e.g., INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP) with family-wise-error corrected whole-brain results and peak MNI coordinates, and describes these maps in the text/tables (including conjunction analyses). Whole-brain results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a clinical subgroup. The study therefore meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy sample) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=16–17 analyzed; age range 21–46) investigating social cognition (attribution/understanding of others’ emotions). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Emotion>Expression conjunction across targets; Face>Scramble; target-dependent whole-brain analyses) with cluster-level FWE correction and ROI complement. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI during viewing of emotional facial expressions (affiliation-relevant emotions) — a clear social-processing task. Sample comprises 40 healthy adult volunteers (within the 17–65 age range). The abstract reports neural responses in multiple brain regions (thalamus, temporo-parietal regions, cerebellum, amygdala, cortical areas) associated with implicit/explicit extraversion during masked and unmasked faces, indicating group-level task-evoked univariate activation results (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses). There is no indication the paper is non-empirical or limited to clinical groups. Thus it satisfies the inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults relevant to social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (attending to facial emotion vs. age) in healthy adults (final N=25; ages 21–33). It uses task-evoked BOLD during an emotion/age attribution task and a face localizer. The paper reports group-level whole-brain second-level analyses (random-effects contrast faces > objects) used to define ROIs, and whole-brain searchlight results (group-level maps/tables/figures) for task and stimulus effects. The sample falls within the 17–65 range, results for the healthy group are reported separately, and the study is empirical task-based fMRI (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task examining social interaction recognition (social cognition). Includes a separate healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8 within 17–65). Reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group with voxelwise results, cluster- and peak-level statistics, and FWE-corrected findings. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately (within-group contrasts), not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of task-evoked whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (Social Feedback task) in a healthy sample (final N=56; age range 17–20, mean 18) which falls within the review’s eligible age range (17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., positive>neutral, negative>neutral; whole-brain FWE-corrected p<0.05) using SPM8 and random-effects analyses. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group activation maps/contrasts are clearly reported and generalizable to the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not clinical-only, not resting-state/ROI-only, and includes whole-brain task activations). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (study 1 n=41, study 2 n=39; ages 18–24) that explicitly examines social-related processing (mentalizing/social cognition and self-related processing) during a task involving reading articles and considering sharing. The authors report group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation by population-level retransmission ranks) with multiple-comparison correction and whole-brain tables/maps described in the text and SI. Results for the healthy samples are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social constructs, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain group-level results).

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (mentalising/higher-order intentionality) using healthy adult participants (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22, all healthy, within 17–65). The analyses are whole-brain, group-level, random-effects voxelwise contrasts (SPM2) including mentalising > factual and parametric modulation contrasts; results are reported with whole-brain correction (P<0.05) and coordinate tables/figures. The task is clearly social-related (theory of mind/mentalising). The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity methods, and it provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (20 participants analyzed, ages 18–55). The task is a social-related imitate/observe emotional faces paradigm targeting perception/understanding of others and empathy. The paper describes whole-brain voxelwise analyses: a univariate GLM in SPM8 (reported as showing similar whole-brain patterns) and spatio-temporal PLS maps with voxelwise bootstrap-ratio maps rendered on MNI brain. Results present group-level spatial activation patterns and brain–behavior correlations across the whole brain. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical fMRI work and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study meets several inclusion criteria (fMRI task addressing social cognition/theory-of-mind in healthy adult participants aged in-range). However, based on the provided full text, the paper does not clearly report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The methods emphasize individually-defined ROIs (based on a subject-level localizer) and MVPA within ROIs; results focus on ROI decoding and Wilcoxon tests across regions. No explicit group-level whole-brain contrast maps, tables of coordinates, or univariate whole-brain activation results for the healthy group are described in the supplied content. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain task effect, and that criterion cannot be verified from the provided text, the study must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (impression-formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status). The sample comprises 60 healthy adult participants (mean age 23.8), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain regressions with voxel-wise thresholding and a reported VMPFC/NAcc cluster; full whole-brain results referenced in supplement), in addition to ROI analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map). No exclusion criteria apply. Inclusion is appropriate.
