This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30 females, age 19–39) investigating social-related processing (kinship, moral dilemma, mentalizing). It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results: inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps across the whole brain and a GLM-based whole-brain analysis of a moral-dilemma decision task, with multiple-comparison correction and cluster tables; unthresholded maps are available on NeuroVault. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and presents generalizable healthy-group task activations, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related perception (body motion, potential for social involvement) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The study reports group-level, task-evoked univariate analyses (first- and second-level GLMs) with voxelwise contrasts and stereotaxic coordinates, thresholded (FWE-corrected) and presented in tables/figures. Although targeted masks for MNS and MS were used for analysis, the paper describes whole-brain second-level contrasts and provides coordinates for significant activations, satisfying the whole-brain univariate reporting requirement. The task probes perception and understanding of others (social cognition), and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36, mean age 22) and reports within-group task contrasts, all reported neuroimaging results are small-volume/ROI-corrected within a vACC mask. The paper does not present or describe unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation maps or whole-brain coordinate tables for healthy adults. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement that at least one group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map be reported; it appears to report only ROI-restricted findings.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction (joint action with haptic contact) examining leading/following and mutual interaction—constructs clearly within social communication and perception/understanding of others. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=18 after exclusion; mean age 40.4, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (multiple contrasts reported with FDR correction and cluster thresholds) and provides Talairach coordinates and statistical maps/tables. Analyses are not limited to ROI or to connectivity/resting-state; healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI on healthy adult participants and reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (within-group male vs female stimuli with FWE-corrected clusters), the experimental paradigm investigates sexual arousal and reward-related responses to erotic stimuli to study sexual orientation. The primary constructs are sexual incentive motivation and reward (ventral striatum) rather than social-related processing (e.g., affiliation/attachment, social communication, or perception/understanding of others as social agents). Thus it does not meet the meta-analysis’ requirement for a social-related task. Therefore the study should be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI (naturalistic movie viewing of Toy Story) that probes social-cognitive processing. A healthy adult group (final N=21 adults) within the 17–65 range is reported separately. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level maps (within-group inter-subject correlation maps and Adult vs Child contrasts) with peak coordinates and multiple-threshold cluster correction; results are described for the adult (healthy) group and are generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Although the analytic approach uses inter-subject correlation rather than a traditional GLM, it yields univariate, voxel/nodewise whole-brain statistical maps for the healthy adult group, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult samples (Experiment 1: N=50, ages 19–34; Experiment 2: N=23, ages 18–30). Tasks probe social interaction perception (interactive vs. non-interactive, cooperation vs. competition) using task-evoked stimuli. The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., social interaction > independent actions) with surface-based random-effects group analysis and FDR-corrected results in the pSTS; coordinates/thresholding and group maps are described. Analyses include whole-brain and ROI-based results, meeting the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports original task-based fMRI data in a healthy adult sample (N=14 analyzed, ages 23–50) using a social-related appraisal task (social vs non-social IAPS images). It includes group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (social > non-social contrast) with voxelwise thresholds and FDR correction and reports significant clusters and conjunction maps. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and healthy controls are analyzed separately. The paper is empirical and not ROI- or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of a social decision task (control aversion) involving perception/understanding of others. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked, whole-brain univariate analyses (paired t-tests, random-effects, cluster-level FWE correction) with reported coordinates and statistical maps (e.g., IPL, dlPFC). Although PPI connectivity is included, the study also reports standard whole-brain activation contrasts, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria are violated. Thus the study fits the review objective and inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 27) that investigates social communicative intent from prosody (a social communication task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and activation maps/coordinates are described. It is not ROI-only and includes task-evoked whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only connectivity or only patient groups, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a social process (empathic accuracy/EAT) in healthy adults (final sample n=34, ages ~20–30). It provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (random-effects models; TFCE FWE-corrected results reported) including contrasts (emotional > neutral, happy vs sad), parametric modulation by empathic accuracy, and time-series correlations with continuous intensity ratings. Results are presented as significant whole-brain clusters (tables/figures) generalizable to a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=59 across three studies) investigating socially relevant processing (person knowledge, socially relevant concept words). Group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts are reported (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster correction, peak coordinates, and whole-brain figures described in the text. Results for the healthy control participants are presented separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not violate exclusion criteria (no resting-state/seed-only analyses, not limited to special populations). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study includes a social cognition task (social interaction vs random movement) using fMRI in healthy adult samples drawn from HCP and UCLA (ages 21–50 and 22–36, within 17–65). The authors performed voxel-wise GLM analyses and report group-level task activations (e.g., Figure 1 and Supplementary Figure S2) for the healthy participants, providing whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps. Although the paper focuses on task-modulated connectivity (PPI/BSC), it explicitly presents whole-brain activation results for the healthy/control group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Thus it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI with whole-brain group-level activation maps in healthy adults.

The sample consists of typically developing adolescents aged 14–18 years (M=16.3); no separate healthy adult (17–65) group is reported. Although the study uses task-based fMRI with group-level whole-brain contrasts (e.g., high positive > neutral) and reports voxelwise clusters, it does not provide results from a healthy adult sample or a healthy adult subgroup analyzed separately. This fails the review’s required sample-age inclusion criterion (healthy adults 17–65). Therefore the study must be excluded.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation using a social-related task (extended Hariri face/scene matching with erotic/attachment and fearful social scenes). Sample comprises 55 healthy adult males (mean age 24.9), meeting the age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., erotic>neutral, fearful>neutral, erotic>fearful) with whole-brain FWE-corrected results and figures/tables describing these effects, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although embedded in a pharmacological (oxytocin/placebo) crossover design, healthy-group whole-brain effects (OT+PLA combined and contrasts) are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, reports healthy-group whole-brain activation maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mind perception/gaze cueing) in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24.4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors) with cluster-based FWER correction and lists significant clusters (e.g., bilateral vmPFC, left TPJ, fusiform, occipital). The healthy control group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants are within the 17–65 range). Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI during a social-related task (approach–avoidance task with social vs nonsocial positive/negative scenes); (2) sample consists of healthy adult participants (male, ages ~21, N analyzed per group reported), with no clinical subgroup required; (3) authors created and analyzed task-evoked first-level contrasts and conducted second-level group analyses and report exploratory whole-brain results beyond a priori ROIs (text states whole-brain analyses reported at P<.05 corrected), providing univariate, group-level task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although many focal findings used ROI/SVC, whole-brain analyses are explicitly reported, and the study is not limited to connectivity or ROI-only reporting. Therefore it is eligible for inclusion.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 22–34). Task: naturalistic social cognition (watching a 20-min movie) with content-coded social interaction events (verbal/non-verbal) — a social-related processing paradigm. Reported whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM results (second-level ANOVA and t-contrasts) with voxelwise FWE correction and cluster reporting; tables and figures of whole-brain activations are provided. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of social impression formation in healthy adult participants (N=60, mean age 23.8) and meets sample and task criteria, the paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map or coordinate table for the healthy group. The reported neuroimaging results are multivariate PLS analyses and bootstrapped brain–behavior correlations; univariate GLM methods are described and univariate results are referenced as coming from a prior analysis, but no univariate whole-brain activation map/contrast (or coordinates/tables/figures) from this study’s healthy group is presented in the manuscript itself. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting a within-group univariate whole-brain task effect.

This is an empirical fMRI study of joint action (leader/follower) tapping social cognition (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing networks such as TPJ, PCC, mPFC are explicitly investigated). Sample: 18 healthy adult participants (mean age ~40), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Leading>Following, Following>Leading, conjunction [Leading>Rest]∩[Following>Rest]) with statistical thresholds, cluster corrections and Talairach coordinates presented in figures/tables. It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state/connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain maps are clearly reported. Although authors note exploratory/limited power, all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adults (N=20 males, ages 21–37). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (one-sample t tests, repeated-measures ANOVAs, flexible factorial models) with FWE cluster-corrected results and tables/figures of activation clusters for task phases (decision, feedback, trust rating). Healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable; inclusion/exclusion criteria (age range, task-based whole-brain maps, not ROI-only, not connectivity-only) are satisfied. Although the sample is male-only, participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group maps are provided. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 18–22) using an interactive social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) that probes social interaction, cooperation and responses to partner behavior. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (thresholded Z>3.1 with FWE cluster correction) and provides whole-brain results (tables/figures) for healthy participants (OT vs placebo conditions and genotype subgroups). The sample is healthy adults and whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported and clearly described. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social processing (trustworthiness appraisal) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=17), the paper does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript mainly reports (1) whole-brain analyses across all participants, (2) between-group contrasts (BPD vs controls), and (3) ROI and mask-based analyses for the amygdala and subject-specific masks. Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one clearly reported whole-brain, univariate healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults (not only ROI or between-group contrasts), this study does not meet all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social provocation (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) in healthy adult males (ages 18–35), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., high > low provocation during feedback and decision phases) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides MNI coordinates and tables of activations for the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and within-group task activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction using a two-person interactive pattern game (cooperation/competition, concurrent vs turn-based), clearly addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others, social communication). Sample: 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4), within the 17–65 range. Neuroimaging: group-level, whole-brain voxelwise GLM analyses were performed (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation inference and threshold-free cluster enhancement; results are reported as whole-brain contrasts and cluster coordinates. The paper reports within-group task-evoked whole-brain effects for the healthy sample (multiple contrasts: main effects and interactions). It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses, nor include only clinical groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

While the study investigates social perception (dynamic facial expression processing) using fMRI in (presumably) healthy adults and targets pSTS for neurofeedback, the provided full-text content does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The methods and results described emphasize a stringent localizer and an ROI-like target region in pSTS and subsequent neurofeedback, suggesting ROI-focused analyses. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported whole-brain healthy-group task activation map (voxelwise or equivalent coordinate-based whole-brain results) and this is not evident from the information provided, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of real-time mutual eye contact, a clear social communication task (shared attention/perception of others). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=30 analyzed for fMRI; mean age ~21.7), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM results (LIVE > REPLAY contrast) with cluster-level FWE correction and detailed coordinates/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although additional connectivity and interbrain analyses are included, they do not replace the presence of univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study used healthy adult participants and investigates social-related processing (perception/recognition of others via faces), the paper emphasizes MVPA/ROI analyses and representational similarity analyses. The full text does not clearly report any group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast with coordinates or whole-brain figures) attributable to the healthy/control group. The methods describe group-level analyses used to derive MVPA patterns and an independent localizer in a separate sample, but no clearly reported whole-brain voxelwise activation map is provided in the supplied text. Therefore the study fails the inclusion criterion requiring reported whole-brain univariate healthy-group task activation and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related Face Processing Task (fearful vs. neutral faces) in healthy adults (n=49; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (Fearful>Neutral and Neutral>Fearful) and associated statistical maps/results using TFCE with FWE correction, and provides coordinates and whole-brain analyses (including exploratory whole-brain and median-split comparisons). Results are clearly reported for the healthy control/participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only and includes univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps, so it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=111, ages 19–36; fMRI groups N=20 each with 19 analyzed), using a task probing animacy perception from motion—a form of Perception and Understanding of Others/social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (conjunction contrasts, whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds, cluster coordinates and figures; significant IPS cluster reported at voxel-wise FWE p<0.05), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/ostracism via Cyberball) in a sample of healthy adult participants (female, mean age 21.7). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate whole-brain analyses and provides peak coordinates for significant effects (e.g., right AI, rTPJ, subACC) derived from contrasts involving the healthy participant groups; whole-brain analyses were conducted (initial threshold p<0.001 uncorrected) with clusters reported (SVC FWE-corrected) and coordinates supplied. The task and contrasts are clearly social-related and the results are generalizable to healthy adults. Although many reported effects are between healthy-subgroup contrasts (support-type vs no support), these are univariate, group-level, voxelwise maps in healthy adults and reported with coordinates, satisfying the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (n=21, ages 18–35) using task-evoked functional MRI. The paradigm directly investigates social interaction processing (arguing, celebrating, laughing) and reports group-level analyses: whole-brain GLMs were run (used to generate beta maps and to create group-constrained, whole-brain localizer contrasts such as interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain) and these localizer contrasts are described and visualized (supplementary materials) to define ROIs. Although the primary reported effects are multivariate (ROI-based MVPA and whole-brain searchlight), the paper clearly includes group-level, univariate, whole-brain task contrasts from healthy participants (the localizers) that meet the review’s requirement for a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map. The sample falls within the eligible age range and no exclusion criteria (connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=31 for fMRI; ages 18–35). The task probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) by presenting faces with/without disfigurement during a gender-judgement cover task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (non-parametric SnPM analysis) with cluster-level FWE correction (p<0.05) showing increased/decreased activations; results are described and shown in figures/tables. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are generalizable to healthy adults, so INCLUDED.

Although this is an fMRI study of vocal emotional processing in healthy adults (N=36) and addresses social communication/ emotion, the paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map. The analyses are ROI/atlas-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical network metrics (Power-264 ROIs, OMSTs) with paired t-tests on FC and network measures. No voxelwise GLM activation maps or whole-brain task contrasts for the healthy group are provided. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies reporting only connectivity/graph analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

The study used fMRI during a social (trust-game) task, but the sample consists of male adolescents aged 13–19 with no separately reported healthy adult (17–65) subgroup. The review requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65) reported separately. Although the paper includes whole-brain task analyses, these are not clearly reported as univariate whole-brain maps for a healthy adult control group generalizable to adults. Therefore it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion (and thus the required healthy adult whole-brain reporting).

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social/neuroeconomic paradigm (prisoner’s dilemma) probing social behavior and social cognition. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15, ages 18–50) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and results for controls (e.g., significant activations in right fusiform gyrus, right superior frontal gyrus, left insula, left superior temporal gyrus during decision-making), as well as one-sample and per-group t-tests and full-factorial analyses (FWE-corrected whole-brain thresholds). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Age range, task relevance, and whole-brain healthy-group contrasts satisfy the inclusion criteria. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy typically-developing (TD) adult control group (age range within 17–65) and uses task-based fMRI during a social (dynamic facial expression) paradigm, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or within-group contrast specifically for the healthy/control group. The paper reports ROI-based group analyses and whole-brain analyses only as between-group (ASD vs TD) comparisons (which yielded no significant group-difference clusters) and focuses on effective connectivity (DCM). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one healthy-group whole-brain univariate task-evoked map (reportable as coordinates/figures/tables), and this is not provided, the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=31, mean age 24.3) using an explicit social task probing trustworthiness/honesty (take advice game and subsequent trust game). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., honesty vs dishonesty, value contrasts) with voxelwise inference and FWE cluster/voxel correction, and provides coordinates and tables. The sample is within the 17–65 range, and results for the healthy group are reported directly. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and includes whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of action perception (perception/understanding of others’ hand actions), a social-related construct. It includes multiple groups of healthy adult participants (total n=79 across Experiments 1–3 and 31 controls in Experiment 5) with group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS and weight discrimination contrasts) reported whole-brain (with maps, conjunctions, and thresholding described). Although a patient group (SCA6) is included, results for healthy controls are reported separately. The paper provides univariate, generalizable healthy-group activation maps (figures, thresholds, ROIs), meeting the review’s inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lack of healthy whole-brain task maps) are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=13, ages 21–41; Experiment 2: N=18, ages 18–33), testing processing of vocal versus non-vocal sounds (socially relevant stimuli). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal and vice versa) with thresholding (FDR-corrected) and presents univariate task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. The task involves social-related processing (voice perception/communication). No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy adult group results are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (observation of interpersonal touch), includes a healthy adult control group (21 neurotypical adults; adults in the 17–65 range implied), and reports group-level univariate whole-brain task effects for the healthy/control group (mean group effects and MNI coordinates for social vs. non-social contrasts are provided in the main/supplementary materials). Although a clinical ASD group is also included, results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical and provides whole-brain voxelwise activation results (not limited to ROI-only or resting-state analyses). Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=24, ages 22–39) investigating social-process-relevant constructs (collective memory, social knowledge, narrative comprehension, dmPFC involvement in representing collective/social schemas). The experiment used a task-evoked fMRI paradigm (recall of museum pictures cued by captions). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (surface-based searchlight, group-level TFCE permutation testing) with significant clusters for the collective-schema effect in mPFC and other regions (Extended Data Fig. 1), not limited to ROI results. All inclusion criteria are met: social-related task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and group-level whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria apply.
